subject: AI
title: Synthetic Eval Data
description: Using LLMs to generate test cases at scale.

hook.text: Writing 500 eval questions by hand takes weeks. What if an LLM generated them? It can â€” but synthetic data has traps.

buildup.text: Feed your documents to an LLM and ask: 'Generate 20 questions a user might ask about this document, with expected answers.' You get volume quickly.

discovery.text: Synthetic eval data is great for coverage testing: 'do we handle questions about topic X?' It's less reliable for precision testing: 'is this exact answer correct?'

twist.text: LLMs generate questions that other LLMs answer well â€” they share the same biases. Synthetic evals can make your system look better than it is. Always mix synthetic with human-written questions.

climax.text: Use synthetic data for breadth (cover many topics), human-written data for depth (test nuanced correctness). Verify a sample of synthetic questions before trusting the whole set.

punchline.text: LLMs can write your test questions. But verify them â€” a biased eval is worse than no eval.

quiz.question: What is the main risk of using purely synthetic eval data?
options: LLMs generate questions with shared biases, making the system look better than it is
It takes longer than writing questions manually
